subject: Photography
title: How Film Captures an Image
description: A 60-second lesson on How Film Captures an Image.

hook.text: Before sensors, photographs were captured by light-sensitive chemicals. Film is chemistry, not electronics.

buildup.text: Film consists of silver halide crystals suspended in gelatin on a plastic base. Light changes the crystals.

discovery.text: Exposed crystals form a latent image â€” invisible until chemical development converts them to metallic silver.

twist.text: The image on developed negative film is reversed: bright areas are dark, dark areas are clear. Printing flips it.

climax.text: Film grain â€” the visible texture â€” comes from clumps of silver crystals. Faster film has larger, more visible grain.

punchline.text: Film is light drawing with chemistry.

quiz.question: What causes grain in film photographs?
options: Clumps of silver halide crystals in the film emulsion
